Award.AwardTitle: RAPID - Collaborative Research - Offshore impacts of the Tohoku-Oki earthquake on seafloor deformation, sedimentation, erosion, tsunamigenesis
Award.AbstractNarration: Great megathrust earthquakes and the tsumanis they generate are among are the greatest threats to populated coastlines worldwide, such as Chile, Sumatra, Alaska, and Cascadia (the regions extending from southern British Columbia into northern California). The risk of catastrophic consequences and the acute need for improved understanding of these events are underscored by the devastation caused by the 11 March 2011 Tohoku-Oki earthquake off northern Japan. While the destruction from these events is acute, they also offer important opportunities to gain new insights into the processes that spawn them. In the wake of the earthquake in Japan, the proponents of this project have been invited to collaborate with Japanese scientists at JAMSTEC (Japan Agency for Marine Earth-science and Technology) to investigate and document the effects of the earthquake offshore. The broader impacts of this program include enhanced international collaboration, and a contribution to instruction at the investigators? respective institutions, but by far the greatest broader impact of this activity is the very high societal relevance of studying these catastrophic events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2011 Mw9 Tohoku earthquake at the Japan Trench was the largest earthquake to occur since the 2004 Mw9.3 Sumatra-Andaman earthquake. The seafloor displacement caused by this rupture generated a large tsunami that was primarily responsible for killing more than 16,000 people and devastating the NE coast of Honshu. Irreparable damage to nuclear reactors at the Fukushima power plant is having long-term national and international consequences. The objective of this project was to initiate collaborations with Japanese scientist to investigate the offshore impacts of the earthquake. Namely, which fault systems were activated, how these fault systems could have had consequences in the generation of the tsunamis, and how were sediments mobilized by fault activity and ground shaking.

The evaluation of seismic hazards associated with faults depends on understanding its seismogenic evolution through time. Major earthquakes along active faults typically recur every few centuries to several millennia, and historical records rarely extend long enough to contribute sufficient information. Earthquake geology, or paleoseismology, is the investigation of individual earthquakes from their geologic signatures, by analysing crustal deformation and sedimentary features produced by ancient earthquakes. Paleoseismology has become a primary tool for seismic hazard evaluation on land, but few paleoseismologic studies are attempted on submarine fault systems. The three investigators have collaborated for several years on developing a methodology for submarine earthquake geology, investigating fault systems in the Marmara Sea (Turkey) and offshore Haiti. In the wake of the devastating 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami, the investigators had initiated collaborations with Japanese scientists at the Japan Agency for Marine Earth-science and Technology (JAMSTEC) to study the causes and effects of that great earthquake. A joint investigation with the same colleagues of the 2011 Japan earthquake came as a natural extension of this prior collaboration. The rupture area of the Tohoku earthquake had been previously surveyed by Japanese scientists in great detail prior to 2011. The 2011 event offers an opportunity to precisely quantify the morphological, sedimentological, and structural changes that occur along a submerged plate boundary during an earthquake.

During the first year of this project, the investigators met in the US and with scientist from JAMSTEC in Japan to develop joint investigations of the Japan Trench. While deep-submergence vehicles are typically limited to surveying in ocean depths of 6000-6500 m, the recently developed American remotely operated vehicle (ROV) Nereus can reach the deepest regions of the Japan Trench, down to 7500 m of water depth. Drs. Kodaira, Fujiwara, and Kanamatsu at JAMSTEC provided the investigators with geophysical data, including multibeam bathymetry, seismic reflection profiles, and high-resolution subbottom profiles. In parallel, Dr. Kanamatsu invited one of the investigators (McHugh) to participate in two research cruises aboard the Research Vessel Natsushima (expeditions NT13-02 and NT13-19), to sample and characterize deposits from the 2011 earthquake, and prior, similar earthquakes. Thirty-one piston cores averaging 5 m in length were recovered in a range of water depths (1000-6000 m) and N-S for 300 km along the trench.

The short-lived radioisotopes Cs-137 and Cs-134 are diagnostic of the 2011 Fukushima nuclear plant disaster. These have been detected in high concentrations in several of the cores collected from 1000-2000 m of water depth, in association with sedimentary structures characteristic of mass-wasting, and possibly documenting a 2011 earthquake triggered deposit.
